Graphical abstract Electrospinning method has been developed as an important jigsaw to solve the fatal LiPSs shuttling, sluggish sulfur redox kinetics and dendrites forming in LSBs. Lithium–sulfur batteries (LSBs) have become promising next-generation energy storage technologies for electric vehicles and portable electronics, due to its excellent theoretical specific energy. However, the low conductivity of sulfur species, notorious lithium dendrites, the severe “shuttle effect” of polysulfides (LiPSs) and the inferior kinetic reaction for LiPSs/Li2S conversion during discharge–charge have seriously hindered their practical application, and also pose potential safety hazards. Owing to their superior porous architectures, high specific surface areas, excellent structural designability, functional modifiability, abundant active sites and flexibility of carbon-containing electrospun nanofibers (CENFs), they exhibited the superior characteristics that can simultaneously solve the above issues. In this review, we summarize the recent progress and application of CENFs in LSBs. First, we provide a brief introduction to the structure and composition controlled of carbon nanofibers by electrospinning. We then review progress in recent developments of CENFs for LSBs including cathodes, anodes, separators, and interlayers. We focus on how to solve practical issues that arise when the CENFs are applied to various parts of LSBs, and the relevant working mechanisms are described, from high sulfur loading and Li dendrites suppression to LiPSs’ confinement and conversion. Finally, we summarize and propose the existing challenges and future prospects of CENFs, for the design and architecture of electrochemical components in Li–S energy storage systems. Keywords Lithium–sulfur batteries Electrospinning Carbon-containing nanofibers Cathodes Anodes Separators and interlayers 1 Introduction Lithium ion batteries (LIBs), devices that realizes stable conversion of electrical energy and chemical energy through the intercalation of lithium ions [1,2], have dominated the energy revolution in the last century [3]. Lithium–sulfur batteries (LSBs) have become a new favorite topic of research, due to their low potential [4,5], high theoretical energy density (1675 mAh g−1 and 2600 Wh kg−1, respectively) and environment-friendly cathode material (sulfur). For these reasons, they could succeed lithium–ion cells. The complexity of parameter regulation for lithium–sulfur electrochemical energy storage system is unmatched by LIBs. Researchers need to improve the ability of cathode to limit sulfur and absorb lithium polysulfides (LiPSs), an intermediate product of discharge. This could be achieved by designing the material and structure of the hosts so as to maximize the utilization of sulfur, thereby improving the specific discharge capacity and inhibit its attenuation. Anode designs should be focused on the concept of a lithiophilic host. The separator region and electrolyte between the cathodes and anodes work together to cut off the shuttle path of LiPSs [6] and regulate the uniform nucleation of lithium, to stabilize and enlarge the electrochemical window of the batteries. Researchers have discussed these arguments, perspectives and commercial applications of LSBs in detail in most of the reports and reviews [6–11]. Carbon materials with porous structures do play a key role in LSBs [12,13]. Researchers have successfully synthesized various porous frameworks for use of Li–S energy storage systems, including carbon microspheres [14,15], carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [16], carbon nanorods (CNRs) [17], graphene-based materials [18,19], biomass carbon materials [20,21], electrospun carbon nanofibers [22], and heteroatom-doped porous carbon-based materials [23–25], etc. Many synthesis methods have been attempted to prepare high-performance carbonaceous materials, as shown and compared in Table 1 . The template method [26,27] is complicated, time consuming and unsuitable for large-scale synthesis. The direct or catalytic pyrolysis of existing materials (such as graphene [28]) or precursors (metal–organic-framework [29,30] and biomass precursors [31,32]) is relatively simple. However, the template, existing materials, or precursors can significantly determine the microstructure and morphology of the product, thus limiting the diversity of its resulting microstructure and morphology. The self-assembly method also has been used to prepare one-dimensional (1D) [33], two-dimensional (2D) [34], or three-dimensional (3D) [35] carbon structures. However, regarding the microstructure and morphology, it is difficult to maintain stability in the assembly steps. The microstructure of these carbon materials is closely related to the performance of the battery. Among them, research into conductive nanofibers [36] has entered the field of electrochemical energy storage, due to their attractive characteristics, such as a high specific surface area (SSA) to volume ratio, bulk conductivity, and surface functional modification. Although pyrolysis methods and electrospinning can both obtain carbon materials with high specific surface area and pore volume, electrospinning has obvious advantages regarding the preparation of 1D carbon nanofibers. Electrospinning is currently a mature technological technique [37], which can allow the manufacture of continuous nanofibers with diameters as small as a few nanometers. In addition, 1D nanofibers with complex structures, such as core–shell fibers or hollow fibers, can be produced by coaxial electrospinning [38,39], and structures of individual nanofibers to ordered nanofibers can be constructed as well. The porous framework of electrospun carbon nanofibers and its ability to uniformly disperse multifunctional nanostructures (nanoparticles [40,41], nanoflakes [42], nanoplates [43] or nanorods [44], etc.) makes it suitable for LSBs requiring high capacity and long-term stability. Researchers believed these multifunctional nanostructures could enhance adsorption with LiPSs. Furthermore, modification of electrospun carbon nanofibers by the introduction of metal–organic-framework (MOF) [45–49] provided similar properties while promoting the conversion of LiPSs. Advances in carbon-containing electrospun nanofibers include microscopic structure, functional modification, excellent conductivity, flexibility and encapsulation of active substances. These plausible overall designs will better regulate the charge and discharge reactions against the LSBs. In addition, electrospun polymer nano felts could now replace traditional polypropylene (PP) or polyethene (PE) separators in regulating the Li+ ions flux in the electrolyte, and in blocking the diffusion of LiPSs to the anode. From a further perspective, electrospun separators can modulate the dissolution and deposition process of lithium to prevent the safety hazards triggered by lithium dendrite formation. Moreover, we can use an electrospun interlayer to integrate the components of LSBs, to improve their conductivity and suppress the transfer of LiPSs. Therefore, many efforts have been taken to develop carbon-containing electrospun nanofibers (including carbon-based or polymer-based materials), and the electrochemical performance of the corresponding LSBs has been distinctly improved. Although many reviews regarding the application of carbon nanomaterials for advanced LSBs have been conducted in the past few years [13,50–53], there are still few comprehensive reviews into carbon-containing electrospun nanofibers (CENFs) as advantageous components for the development of LSBs [39]. In this review, we will provide a comprehensive discussion of the state-of-the-art research activities regarding the development and application of CENFs in LSBs, including cathodes, anodes, separators and interlayers. The ways in which CENFs can solve the electrochemical issues in the Li–S energy storage system will be revealed as much as possible, to uncover the working mechanisms in respect to high sulfur loading, Li dendrites suppression, LiPSs confinement and conversion. We also propose the challenges and prospects of CENFs for the design and architecture of electrochemical components in Li-S energy storage systems. 2 Design and fabrication of carbon-containing electrospun nanofibers Electrospinning is an intensely convenient and therefore easy-to-control technology for producing fibers with dimensions in the range of hundreds of nanometers. It has been widely applied to many fields, fields such as optoelectronics [54], sensor technology [55], catalysis [56], filtration [57], medicine [58], etc. To fabricate carbon-based electrospun nanofibers (CNFs), first a solution formed by a polymer and a solvent with an appropriate phase is placed in a syringe as fiber-forming materials. Then, the polymer solution is pumped through a stainless-steel needle with a smaller inner diameter and accepted by a conductive collecting device. At the same time, the needle and the receiving equipment are used as electrodes to apply a high electric field. The high voltage (~15 kV) means that the electrostatic droplets are stretched by the electric field force to form 1D fibers following the evaporation of the solvent. Finally, these fibers are deposited on collecting devices and form non-woven film webs without accumulating. In principle, the shape and size of the CENFs depend significantly on the electrospinning parameters, such as the concentration, viscosity, and conductivity of the polymer solution, the injection rate of the solution and the strength and form of the electric field. Moreover, electrospinning can be carried out either “from bottom to top” or horizontally, which also plays an important role in fibers formation. Compare with 3D confined nanoparticles, CENFs can be modified into multilevel structures. These multilevel structured fibrous nanomaterials are attractive because they offer a larger SSA and additional structural interfaces, which play paramount roles in enhancing the different nano-sized structures. Therefore, electrospun products with structures such as solid fibers, porous fibers, core–shell fibers, nanotubes and nanowires can be applied to the development of different promising materials for LSBs and have attracted considerable attention. 2.1 Structural modification The basic principle of electrospinning is based on the uniaxial elongation of electrospinning solution that consists of organic polymer and corresponding solvent. Organic polymers include polyacrylonitrile (PAN) [40,59–61], poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) [62], poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) [63–65], poly (vinyl pyrrolidone) (PVP) [63,65,66], poly (vinyl alcohol) (PVA) [67–69], polyimide (PI) [70], polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) [71], polystyrene (PS) [72] or mixtures of the above polymers. These organic polymers are generally dissolved in one or more solvents, such as N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO), tetrahydrofuran (THF), ethanol (EtOH), mineral oil or water. During the elongation of the viscous electrospinning solution, continuous nanofibers are easily obtained due to the electrostatic traction driven by the electric field. The use of electrospinning technology to obtain organic fabrics, and the use of high-temperature carbonization processes to construct CENFs with high electrochemical activity, are the subject of considerable amounts of research. The process through which polymer nanofibers change into CENFs is relatively complex, involving transformation, and then the removal or retention of structures, elements or chemical compositions. CENFs with porous and tailored structures have been proposed to further improve the electrochemical performance of LSBs. The partial oxidation of CENFs by treatment with air is a convenient method to form pores on their surface. For instance, Li et al. [73] used PAN as carbon residue organic polymer to produce CENFs and then treated it with oxygen to form pores by introducing air of a quantitative volume into Ar (Fig. 1 a). This results in the formation of several micro/mesopores and an increase of SSA. The process of adding templates [36] to a polymer solution are also regarded as shared ways to get porous nanofibers. Hard templates such as Si or SiO2 particles, could be used as pore-forming phases and removed by HF etching [74] or alkali reduction [75] to modify the pore features of CENFs. Similarly, Wu et al. [76] encapsulated nickel particles into PAN fibers and converted them into carbon fibers with high graphitization degree at low temperature. With the removal of non-metallic components of the metal salt precursor, mesopores that were slightly larger than the metal nanoparticles were formed in situ. Subsequently, after the in-situ catalytic graphitization and acid washing of nickel nanoparticles, the product was shown to comprise uniformly arranged carbon nanofibers wrapped with hollow graphite spheres (Fig. 1b). The pore sizes were distributed in the range of 2 ~ 20 nm (Fig. 1b3). The value of I D/(I D + I G) in the Raman spectrum of 0.454 (Fig. 1b4) indicated that the use of metal particles as templates not only introduced a multitude of nanopores, but also feasibly enhanced the graphitization degree of CENFs. Using decomposition above temperature of ~500 °C, such as PMMA, PS, or PVP in PAN electrospinning solution as soft templates, is another strategy to improve the pore structures of the carbonized CENFs. The larger PS or PMMA droplets in the electrospinning solution can be uniformly stretched by the traction of the electric field force. This process can form daintier fibers structures in the coarser PAN fibers. Thus, single or multiple tubular channels were fabricated in CENFs using high-temperature carbonization by tuning the added amount of either PMMA or PS [72] (Fig. 2 a). While the PVP [77] droplets are smaller and are uniformly dispersed in the electrospinning solution, uniform pores are formed in the CENFs after calcination (Fig. 2b). Therefore, the type and concentration of soft templates, as well as the way in which templates dry, significantly influences the pore structures and distributions. Furthermore, micropores can also be increased and refined via physical or chemical activation by KOH [64]. The hierarchical porous frameworks of CENFs often have a positive effect on electrochemical performance. For example, in a secondary battery, porous materials with graded pore sizes can improve the whole charging and discharging reaction process. Smaller pore sizes can contain active substances that improve the stable cycle performance of the battery, while larger ones can be used as channels for electrolyte, to improve the rate performance of the battery [78]. In the early stage of the application of CENFs for electrochemical energy storage, pore control was only used as a prerequisite to accelerate reaction masses transfer. The introduction of active sites (e.g. elemental doping and active substances) was also required to achieve the purpose of promoting electrochemical reaction. However, further increasing their porosity and conductivity simultaneously remained challenging. Recently, Yan et al. [79] reported chemical crosslinking electrospinning for the scalable fabrication of sponge-like CENFs (PCNFs). Such PCNFs exhibited highly controlled trimodal porous structures that contained macro-, meso-, and micro-pores. Moreover, the additional elemental doping of F and B greatly enhanced the conductivity. Using these PCNF films as scaffolds for sulfur cathodes, the resulting batteries delivered high discharge capacities (>1000 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles) at a high rate of 1 C. The framework structure of CENFs can be modified through the aforementioned methods, with the addition of doping in their element composition. Moreover, existing materials with known structure and element compositions can also be introduced into CENFs. The electrospinning process is not only simple and achievable but also makes the diversified requirements for growing the target CENFs both realistic and considerable. 2.2 Structural dispersion With the latest advances in nanoscience and nanotechnology, carbon nanostructures such as carbon nanotube (CNTs) [80,81], graphene sheets [82,83], have been promising candidates for electrode materials of secondary batteries with an ultra-high specific capacity. However, some serious problems associated with various nanostructured carbon materials, such as large volume change and poor cycle, have attracted increasing attention in recent years. Moreover, if these carbon nanostructures are prepared separately, they regroup due to their interfacial interactions. This aggregation inevitably leads to a low SSA of the electrode and a limited diffusion distance between ions and the electrode, limiting their electrochemical performance accordingly. To further overcome these shortcomings, using electrospinning to uniformly disperse and fix these carbon nanostructures has been proposed [84,85]. Usually, carbon nanostructures are directly added to the electrospinning solution and then uniformly dispersed in the fabrics instead of in the form of large particle aggregation after electrospinning, thus, the carbon nanostructures and their large SSA can be maintained to the greatest extent after high-temperature carbonization. Meantime, the porosity and conductivity would further improve by pore-forming or activation [78]. Moreover, the multi-dimensional carbon structures (sheets or tubes shown in Fig. 3 ) can be compounded to construct a 3D interconnected structure [86] via electrospinning. These 3D interconnected CENFs demonstrated large SSA, high porous structural interconnection and high conductivity, thus enhancing their electrochemical performance. This is precisely the advantage of using electrospinning to uniformly disperse and fix existing carbon nanostructures. Moreover, in practical application, these uniformly dispersed and dense nano-scale carbon phases on the anode will shorten the diffusion distance of Li+, improve the rate performance at high current and will reduce the malignant changes triggered by lithium plating/stripping process, fracturing and volume expansion. Table 2 listed several pure carbon-based host materials that are fabricated by electrospinning. They exhibited good potential as a sulfur host, and exhibited high charging/discharging capacity and cycle stability in the slow charging and discharging process of the whole battery. Whether through artificially introducing convenient pyrolytic polymer to increase pore or through dispersing pre-prepared carbon nanostructures uniformly in the CENFs, the utilization of sulfur can be effectively improved. However, pure carbon CENFs are still limited, due to their excessive carbon fibrous skeletons and their inefficient ions transport channels. Although the conductivity of the carbon nanofibers can be improved by metal catalytic graphitization or introduction of graphene/CNTs, the insufficient physical contact between these nanofibers leads to the electrode having a huge contact resistance and low electrical conductivity. This results in poor rate performances at high current. The formation of multi-dimensional cross-linked structures of multi-phase pores may be an effective way to reduce the formation of contact resistance. In summary, the porous structures of CENFs with different sizes indeed enlarge the surface available to contact with electrolyte while the Li+ flux could be stable. Moreover, CENFs with operational reliability and satisfactory mechanical properties prepared by electrospinning can be used to build high-performance flexible devices. Its flexibility and highly conductivity unquestionably make it promising for application in flexible LSBs. However, the weak physical (intermolecular force) confinement effects between LiPSs and nonpolar host cannot effectively restrain the shuttle effect of LiPSs. This results in high-efficiency mass transport, which might promote the dissolution of LiPSs in the electrolyte, thereby accelerating its shuttling. 3 Emerging roles of diverse CENFs in lithium-sulfur batteries CENFs play different roles in each region of electrochemical reactions during the charge and discharge of LSBs. Before high-temperature treatment, electrospun polymer fibers can be directly used as a separator. After carbonization, they can be used as host materials for cathode and anode active substances. Electrospinning is widely used in LSBs, and has far-reaching effects. In this section, the structural design and modification of CENFs for electrochemical application as different components of LSBs is discussed. The focus on this section is how to solve the engineering problems of the LSBs, regarding the following aspects of cathode, anode, separator and interlayer. The application of electrospinning in the synthesis of components for LSBs has the advantages of high speed, high efficiency, high yield, easy control and uniform dispersion, etc. Besides, nanostructures of metal or metal compound (e.g. metal sulfide [87], oxide [88] or nitride [89]) and metal salts (e.g. metal chloride, nitrate, carbonate, acetate acetylacetone) can be dispersed in the viscous electrospinning solution, resulting in some electrochemically active sites in CENFs, to a certain extent. Furthermore, flexible and foldable self-supporting carbon-containing electrodes without binders, nanofiber membranes with thin web micro morphologies and components with integral structures can also be prepared through electrospinning. In preparing inflexible and self-supporting host without binders. Compared with other flexible carbon, such as fiber network-like carbon materials, graphene [90,91] or carbon nanotube sponges [92], CENFs have some advantages. Although graphene and carbon nanotube sponge-like carbon materials have extremely high SSA, the demand for electrolyte will be very high and the preparation methods are not suitable industrial production. The fiber network-like carbon materials obtained from carbonized biomass fiber precursors (such as cotton [92,93]) are of little help to the limitation of LiPSs, and the price of modified flexible carbon cloth [94] is extremely expensive (60 $/m2). In addition, these fibers’ diameters are about 5–10 μm, which is unfavorable to increase the volumetric energy density. More importantly, it is difficult to regulate the pore structure on these flexible substrates. In addition to the characteristics of high porosity and high specific surface area like other flexible carbon, CENFs have the following advantages: (1) Electrospinning technology can realize the controllable design of the pore structure of carbon fibers by tuning the experimental condition, and carbon fibers with the diameter less than 1 μm can be woven into flexible fiber felts to increase the volumetric energy density; (2) The orientation and rapid migration of electrons and ions in the ECNFs can achieve due to the close contact between 1D structure; (3) The active sites can be uniformly dispersed in the ECNFs, thus guarantee the uniform exposure and stable existence of the active sites. This could avoid the large accumulation of LiPSs and the LiPSs/Li2S conversion could proceed on uniformly distributive sites; (4) Electrospinning technology can provide an approach to integrate the components of LSBs from the cathodes to the anodes, which would exhibit excellent interface compatibility and electrolyte wettability. To some extent, the volume of full LSBs can reduce, and the amount of electrolyte will decrease by tuning the pore structure, electrolyte wettability and controllable design of gradient porous components, which is conducive to improving energy density. These advantages will play important roles in fabricating flexible energy storage devices and improving the performance of LSBs. 3.1 Cathode Considerable research progress has been achieved to develop LSBs with high energy density and excellent cycle stability [6]. However, there will be many obstacles to basic research in the laboratory and the high requirements of industrial application [95]. The design of electrode materials has always been the main focus in the field of LSBs, whereas the application of electrospinning in the synthesis of cathode materials for LSBs has gradually gained attention. By virtue of the conductive characteristics and porous structures of CENFs, the sulfur that participates in electrochemical reactions can be fully utilized. In addition, heteroatoms metal, nanoparticles or good conductive compounds could be doped and uniformly dispersed in CENFs, and can make the electrode materials acquire polarity at the same time. This can enhance the ability to limit the shuttles effect of LiPSs. What is more, through feasible activation for the electrochemical reactions inside the battery, these additives can also catalyze the mutual conversion processes between LiPSs/Li2S, and can finally solve the sluggish kinetics of the Li–S energy storage system. 3.1.1 High sulfur content and physical confinement The problem of designing conductive host materials with microstructure to lock sulfur and disperse it uniformly is as yet unsolved. The characteristic of carbonaceous host materials directly affects the reactivity of sulfur, and contribute to the final capacity. To solve volume expansion and sulfur loss, researchers often use hierarchical pore size materials (mainly porous carbon) to encapsulate sulfur. Regarding the relationship between constructing a sulfur host and improving LSBs’ performance, researchers have always considered the unique advantages of hollow structure [96]. From this point of view, CENFs allow for sulfur to be loaded in the hollow structures, rather than only on the exposed surfaces. At the same time, they will also alleviate the harmful volume expansion of active sulfur during lithiation. Secondly, hollow structures in CENFs can be used as physical/chemical barriers to block active sulfur materials, making it difficult for them to escape. Finally, the construction of polar compounds on CENFs will also facilitate the restriction of the shuttle effect, this will achieve the purpose of controlling capacity loss. The specific method of preparing sulfur/carbon composite cathode is indispensable, which is dependent on the capacity of host material to load sulfur. When the areal loading of as-fabricated sulfur/carbon composite is lower than that of 2.5 mg cm−2, there are two common methods to composite the carbon host and sulfur. In the first method, the sulfur particles could fill in the pores of the carbon host adequately by the slow disproportionation of thiosulfates (S2O3 2–) under acidic conditions. However, the overall conductivity of the sulfur/carbon composite may decrease and the full utilization of sulfur may not achieve [13]. Therefore, most sulfur/carbon composite cathodes were prepared usually by the second method, a so-called molten sulfur injection. The liquid sulfur under 155 °C could be adsorbed into the porous carbon host through the capillary force of the pores and then cooled to form sulfur particles. The capillary force dominates the sulfur content. Therefore, porous 3D network structures are necessary and CENFs has obvious advantages in in the aspect of porous structure. When the areal loading of the sulfur/carbon composite is higher than 2.5 mg cm−2, increasing research work employed CENFs as the carbon host. In most cases, molten sulfur injection can be used to fabricate CENFs/S composite cathodes. But if self-supporting flexible CENFs cathodes are too thick, the liquid sulfur cannot achieve enough interface contact. At this time, CENFs can be immersed or be dropped by dissolved S/CS2 solution, and then the network structure in CENFs would be filled by S/CS2. After evaporation of CS2, sulfurs were retained in the pores and the uniform distribution of sulfur can also been achieved. At the end, a heat-treatment slightly higher than 155 °C are usually required to remove the rigid sulfurs that remain on the electrode surface. CENFs with abundant porous structures or/and hollow structures have been proved to improve the sulfur loading and utilization of LSBs, as shown in Table 2. As pore structures have gradually improved, the use of CENFs as a host has significantly improved the content of active sulfur, which has been attributed to the spatial structures on and between carbonaceous nanofibers. In order to ensure the stable influence of areal loading in energy density [97], the thickness of the electrode also needs to be controlled [6]. Fortunately, CENFs are able to fully contact with and adhere onto the current collector. They can also develop flexible electrodes without a binder. Under a binder-free design [98], hosts can maximize the specific energy of LSBs by increasing areal loading to above 5 mg cm−2 [99], and most flexible CENFs hosts have achieved this benchmark according to most reports [27,31,33,39,100], unlike other methods. Recently, Ji et al. [78] has reported the fabrication of a self-supporting flexible carbon film through the electrospinning of PAN, using PMMA as a soft pore-forming agent. Through low-temperature peroxidation and high-temperature carbonization, the carbon film composed of CENFs have been equipped with pores to host sulfur, as shown in Fig. 4 . The adsorption and dispersion between sulfur and host are effectively improved by this method. The as-prepared porous CENF-S nanocomposites were then loaded with 42 wt% S. Their initial two cycles at a rate of 0.02 C then nearly reached the theoretical value of 1675 mAh g−1. When operated at a higher rate of 0.1 C, the capacity remained at approximately 1057 mAh g−1. The ratio of pore-forming phases can be chosen to improve porous nanofibers’ ability for sulfur loading. When the amount of pore-forming agent was increased, the number of pores formed obviously increased, leading to an obvious difference in volume. This meant that more dispersed sulfur particles were introduced into the host on the premise of maintaining its size, thus increased sulfur loading to some extent. By selecting the appropriate removable organic template and dispersing it in the core of the CENFs, 1D hollow [63,101] or multi-channel [64,72,102] nanofibers carbon can be formed. The multi-channel porous carbon nanofibers usually composed of large pores (>50 nm) as well a porous network structure. Ji et al. [103] found that sulfur has its lowest viscosity at 155 °C during the preparation process of sulfur/carbon composite electrode materials, which enables liquid sulfur to fully infiltrate the surface of the porous carbon matrix. Thus, these pores in multi-channel porous carbon nanofibers can provide spaces for increased sulfur loading. This effectively realises the advantage of these porous spaces. At the initial stage of the charging and discharging of the LSBs, the electrolyte will gradually soak the sulfur that is dispersed in the macropores. However, for larger volume sulfur particles, the sulfur in the electrolyte will not be fully utilized. If the spaces for containing sulfur particles are narrower, such as micropores and mesopores, then the sulfur will be better and more evenly soaked by the electrolyte, and will fully participate in the charging and discharging reaction. Sulfur utilization raises as pore size decreases. Theoretically, nanoparticle sized sulfur [104], or even sulfur quantum dots [105] and smaller sulfur molecules [106], should show capacity performance. Therefore, it is of practical significance to add micropores and mesopores to multi-channel carbon fibers, to further reduce the size of encapsulated sulfur particles. Highly reactive materials can react with carbon to functionalize it, making it possible to introduce indispensable micropores and mesopores at the same time. Lee et al. [64] treated MCNFs (Multichannel carbon nanofiber) via a KOH activation process. The SSA of the modified activated nanofibers increased from 983 to 1617 m2 g−1, and new mesopores appeared on the tube wall of the channels in the fibers. The sulfur loading increased (53–80 wt%), whereas the specific capacity was maintained above 920 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at a rate of 0.2 C (79% of the initial value). Similarly, single-channel porous carbon nanotubes [63] can be obtained by coaxial electrospinning, using KOH or ZnCl2 activation to form mesopores. This further indicates that the introduction of micropores and mesopores into porous carbon nanofibers can improve the sulfur loading and utilization in LSBs. Porous CENFs with micropores and mesopores not only improve the sulfur loading ability, but also provide a space for the host, where sulfur and electrolyte can fully contact each other. This ensures a certain effective sulfur utilization, while maintaining a high sulfur loading ability. Although small sulfur particles can be encapsulated in the graded pore structure of porous CENFs to ensure the high performance of LSBs during the initial cycles, the physical confinement of the structural regulation of porous CENFs cannot efficiently inhibit the shuttling of LiPSs. To prevent the shuttling of LiPSs and enhance the cycling stability, Li et al. [72] coated a thin EFG (ethylenediamine-functionalized reduced graphene oxide) layer outside of a multichannel carbon nanofibers/S electrode. This thin EFG layer effectively suppresses the shuttle of LiPSs from the cathode side, and maintain excellent cycling stability, with a reversible capacity of 950 mAh g−1 (at 0.2 C) after 200 cycles. In comparison, an electrode without an EFG layer suffers from steady capacity decay, with a discharge capacity of 623 mAh g−1 (at 0.2 C rate) at the 140th cycle. Under various C-rates from 0.1 to 2 C, an EFG coated electrode can recover most of the original capacity (~1300 mAh g−1) when the current rates is reduced abruptly back to 0.1 C again. This indicates the outstanding stability and robustness of EFG-modified multichannel carbon nanofibers/S electrodes. The use of porous CENFs ensures the uniform dispersion and high utilization of sulfur and achieves the high capacity at the initial cycle. However, the shortcomings of pure carbon hosts are that nonpolar hosts cannot respond positively to the shuttle effect of LiPSs, and that their bare physical confinement ability has little effect on stabilizing the battery cycle. 3.1.2 LiPSs confinement and catalysis Under constant current charging and discharging, mutual conversion among various LiPSs frequently occurs. Low-order LiPSs will inevitably nucleate and precipitate on the surface of the cathode to form dead sulfur, result in irreversible capacity loss. High-order LiPSs will dissolve into the electrolyte, shuttle to the anode through the separator and react with highly enriched Li+ to form low-order insoluble LiPSs. These low-order insoluble LiPSs will similarly nucleate on the surface of anode, eventually causing the deactivation and self-discharge of the lithium anode. As a result, the cycle performance of LSBs will be greatly affected, leading to them eventually needing to be scrapped due to potential safety hazards. The above problems can be attributed to the fact that the LiPSs produced in the charge–discharge reaction cannot be effectively regulated; this is beyond the physical confinement of the pore structure of pure carbon CENFs. Moreover, pure carbon CENFs with developed structure are nonpolar, and cannot provide the function of adsorbing LiPSs to inhibit their shuttling. Therefore, many researchers have planted heteroatoms or polar compounds into/onto CENFs to restrict the shuttling effect of LiPSs and improve the reaction kinetics of LiPSs’ conversion. The eventual aim to this is to control capacity loss. Hollow and porous structures could make CENFs more operable in the construction of active sites [96]. Further construction of active sites that can prevent LSBs capacity loss via the adsorption and conversion of LiPSs will be discussed in this section. Initially, researchers [23] believed that the doping of heteroatoms based on pure carbon materials would polarize the bonding sites of carbon atoms and heteroatoms in the lattice sites of carbon materials, thus enhancing the adsorption and interaction between LiPSs and the carbon hosts. It was previously been noted that CENFs obtained by electrospinning of PAN were nitrogen-doped carbon materials. However, the amount of nitrogen atoms is not sufficient to provide pyridinic N or pyrrolic N, which have the ability to anchor LiPSs. The N atom content can be increased through the surface polymerization of poly-pyrrole [107], poly-dopamine [108] or poly-aniline [109] on CENFs. Calcination can further turn N functional groups to different amounts of pyridinic N or pyrrolic N. Due to the different positions of N atoms in the carbon lattice, their adsorption capacity for LiPSs also differ. Usually, pyrrolic N has a stronger adsorption capacity – nearly twice that of pyridinic N [110]. N doping not only anchors LiPSs, but also improves the conductivity of carbon-based materials, thus further increasing their electrons conduction. Besides, other heteroatom doping, such as O, S, B or P [111], can also generate polarity, and can bring bonding capability with LiPSs. Therefore, the doping of heteroatoms in CENFs is a promising and effective strategy to achieve chemical adsorption with LiPSs and inhibit their shuttling, thus improve the cycle performance of LSBs. When doping with heteroatoms, it is also important to maintain the present structure of CENFs and to introduce added nanostructures into CENFs. Chen et al. [112] reported a uniformly MOF dispersed PAN nanofiber via electrospinning. After a chemical vapor deposition (CVD) treatment, not only was the cubic structure of MOF uniformly dispersed and retained in CENFs, but CNTs also formed in-situ, thus enriching the pore structure of CENFs (Fig. 5 ). The CENFs also string the carbon cubic fillers together, to provide improved electrical contact and excellent long-range conductivity in the entire matrix. This realizes fast sulfur redox kinetics, even under high sulfur loading. Furthermore, carbon nanotubes rooted in carbon cubic fillers not only provide N-doping and metallic sites for LiPSs chemical adsorption but also intertwine with the junctions between hierarchical fibers to enhance structural integrity and promote electrons conduction in the entire CENFs. The structural advantages of the developed cathodic protection device enable the corresponding sulfur electrode to have a high sulfur utilization, rapid reaction kinetics and excellent cycle performance at high gravimetric (348.8 Wh kg−1) and volumetric energy densities (327.6 Wh L–1) respectively, even under the conditions of high sulfur loading of 13.5 mg cm−2 and lean electrolyte of 3 mL g−1. It should be emphasized that the addition of polar components is another crucial and notable method to confine LiPSs. Yu et al. [113] designed a flexible free-standing CENFs in situ, embedded with TiN-VN heterostructures (TiN-VN@CNFs) as an advanced host for the cathode (Fig. 6 ). The Li2S6 adsorption measurements and Li2S precipitation experiments verified the strong anchoring ability for LiPSs and the improved catalytic effect for the LiPSs transformation process. The results demonstrated the polar TiN-VN heterostructures in CENFs greatly suppress LiPSs shuttling, and that the promotion of redox kinetics and the purpose of adjusting Li2S redox reaction has been achieved. The performance of LSBs can be further improved by adjusting the structure and morphology of adding polar materials. For instance, Li et al. [114] dispersed TiO2 coated SiO2 nanospheres in PAN polymer solution and then conducted electrospinning (Fig. 7 ). After annealing, KOH etching and high-temperature reduction, a grape-cluster-like titanium monoxide@carbon hollow fibers (GC-TiO@CHF) was produced. The GC-TiO@CHF/S electrode delivered a high initial capacity of 1,172 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, exhibited superior cycling stability and maintained a capacity of above 680 mAh g−1 over 400 cycles with high-sulfur-loading (5 mg cm−2). The high specific/areal capacity, promising rate capability, and stable cycle life were achieved through mesopore TiO packaging. As pores’ morphology are more feasible to control, LiPSs can be regulated during the discharging process. The carbon framework can perform connecting and conducting functions, and TiO plays a paramount role in limiting the loss of polysulfides to the organic electrolyte, effectively hindering the dissolution of polysulfides. In summary, adding polar materials and tuning the porous structures and morphology of CENFs both play a crucial role in improving the performance of LSBs. Table 3 lists and compares several polar metal compounds, including TiO2 [115], TiN [116], MoO2 [117], MnO2 [118], and Mn3O4 [119], that are available for flexible free-standing CENFs composites prepared by electrospinning. We believe that other sufficient polar materials (metal oxide V2O3, V2O5, MnO2 or metal sulfide MoS2, FeS, TiS2, etc. [120–122]) can also be combined with CENFs and arranged into elaborate structures through electrospinning. Then, many improvements, such as short-range polar host confinement, can be embodied to improve sulfur utilization, and long-range good conductivity can be used to reduce electrochemical resistance. In addition, the LiPSs will be adsorbed onto these polar materials in time, and the shuttling of the LiPSs to the anode will be inhibited, thus reducing the LiPSs’ dissolution in the electrolyte. Similar to other common catalytic active sites using in LSBs, the doping of heteroatoms or the introduction of polar composites in CENFs would bring an additional catalytic conversion effect to the sulfur cathode and improve the reaction kinetics of the LiPSs’ conversion, which significantly affected the battery performance. Furthermore, the 1D orientation of CENFs could regulate rapid conduction of electrons and ions, which ensure the reversible reaction as full as possible. It's worth mentioning that CENFs could guarantee the uniform dispersion and stable existence of catalytic active sites, which avoided the large accumulation of LiPSs and promoted the ordered long chain of LiPSs to convert into short chain of LiPSs continuously. Moreover, the final nucleation of Li2S would uniformly distribute on these active sites, which will ensure the oxidation reaction of poorly conductive Li2S at the next charging can start and proceed forward. This will eventually lead to a steady improvement in the cycle performance of LSBs. However, it is still crucial to determine how to uniformly disperse these polar materials into the CENF, while also keeping and improving their hierarchically porous structures by optimizing the parameters and process of electrospinning. Improving nanostructures and morphologies of polar materials, or structurally compounding of different polar materials before electrospinning, should also be topic for further study. Compared with other sulfur hosts, the fast conversion ratio between soluble LiPSs and Li2S2/Li2S on the surface of the 3D framework of CENFs is more advantageous, especially when it is necessary to improve the sulfur utilization rate under high sulfur content. First, the thermal decomposition of pore-forming agents, when activation by KOH, formed uniform pores in CENFs that could increase the sulfur content through physical confinement. The tubular structures formed by coaxial electrospinning could further optimize the process of improving capacity. Second, the uniform dispersion of heteroatoms or polar compounds in CENFs enhances their ability to limit the shuttling of LiPSs. These active sites have even catalyzed the mutual conversion processes between LiPSs/Li2S, and have finally solved the sluggish kinetics of the Li–S energy storage system. In addition, the low electrons and ionic resistance of CENFs has also enhanced the sluggish reaction kinetics of adsorbed LiPSs through the easy transport of ions/electrons (i.e. fast electrocatalysis). This cannot be achieved by other host without 1D nanofibers and hierarchical structures. Furthermore, the excellent infiltrating ability of CENFs enables the electrode to contact the electrolyte fully, even under compounded high sulfur content. 3.2 Anode In liquid electrolyte LSBs, Li reacts spontaneously with solvent molecules and salt anions to form an insoluble layer of solid electrolyte interface (SEI) [123]. However, Li foil undergoes almost infinite relative volume changes during plating/stripping, resulting in mechanical instability and the formation of cracks in the SEI layer. These cracks can expose the fresh Li below, locally enhancing the Li+ flux and resulting in uneven Li growth (Li dendrites and filaments). This may cause an internal short circuit and thermal runaway. In addition, large surface areas of dendritic Li growth can lead to a continuous loss of lithium and the consumption of electrolyte (as SEI is formed repeatedly). These processes result in a low Coulombic efficiency (CE) and increase the internal resistance of the cell. The surface of carbonaceous materials [124,125] have excellent electrical conductivity, good mechanical properties, chemical stability, low weight density and high SSAs. Therefore, CENFs can be used to fabricate a 3D composite Li anode as a host for Li deposition/dissolution, via either Li melt infusion or Li metal electrodeposition [126–128]. This solves the problems of lithium dendrite growth, and reduces the infinite relative volume change during lithium plating/striping cycles. Lang et al. [129] found that the porous CENFs fabricated by electrospinning demonstrated improved wettability with molten Li, after heat treatment at 1200 °C. After gradually melting and injecting Li into high-temperature thermal treatment CENFs, the obtained 3D composite Li electrode demonstrated a porous structure. The 3D carbon framework was uniformly covered with Li (Fig. 8 ), not only serving as the host for uniform Li plating/stripping, but also providing the skeleton for rapid electron/ion transport. Electrochemical results demonstrated that the 3D composite Li anode achieved a lower overpotential and a flatter voltage profile at different current densities, and no dendrite growth was observed after 100 cycles at a current density of 1.0 mA cm−2. The correlation between Li plating behavior and the surface characteristics of electrospun porous carbon nanofibers (PCNFs) has been systemically elucidated by Cui et al. [130]. They revealed that open pores produced on the PCNF surface served as active sites for the controlled initial nucleation of Li, and stable Li dissolution/deposition (Fig. 9 ). In addition, the introduction of oxygenated functional groups further facilitated the uniform nucleation and growth of Li on the PCNF surface, enabling efficient use of the whole carbon surface. After Li metal was electrodeposited onto the HNO3 modified PCNF via a half cell, the full LSBs were assembled. They delivered an excellent electrochemical performance with, maintaining energy density of 385 Wh kg−1 after 100 cycles at a rate of 0.2 C. By taking advantage of the dispersion that can be achieved through electrospinning, the controllable introduction of lithophilic nanoparticles (Au, Ag) could further improve the lithiophility and conductivity of porous CENFs. Hu et al. [131] soaked porous CENFs with silver acetate solution via vacuum infiltration and used a rapid electric Joule heating method to synthesize ultrafine Ag nanoparticles that were uniformly dispersed on the CENFs (Fig. 10 ). The Ag nanoparticles can serve as nano seeds on 3D host materials to regulate the Li deposition behavior and inhibit the Li dendrites. They can reduce the nucleation overpotential of Li, resulting in a smooth Li anode coated on the CENFs without dendrites. The resultant Li anode, using the Ag NPs modified CENFs, exhibited a negligible nucleation overpotential (≈0.025 V) and demonstrated excellent plating/stripping stability over 500 h, without short-circuiting problems. Porous CENFs have excellent electric conductivity, good mechanical flexibility and sufficient adhesion to the Li anode. Furthermore, the excellent wettability ability of CENFs to the electrolyte enables the electrode to contact the electrolyte fully. The Li host constructed by CENFs provides 3D porous structures, and these porous structures lead to the well-confined Li dissolution/deposition behavior. This accommodates large volume changes, and effectively suppresses dendrite growth. Compared with common Li foils, CENFs have a rough surface that is in full contact with the electrolyte, which reduce ionic resistance. Furthermore, the regulation of the spatial structure creates a good prerequisite for Li deposition. The uniform distribution of the lithiophilic sites on the surface of CENFs can accelerate the electrocatalytic process during Li plating/stripping, by controlling the mass transfer resistance of Li ions. When sufficient interface contact can be ensured, uniform lithium plating/stripping can finally be realized, in both charging and discharging. Therefore, Li, when uniformly coated on the surface of the porous CENFs with high SSA, exhibits better interface stability than Li foils in the plating/stripping process. Whether the porous CENFs are carbonized by heat treatment or directly surface-modified, or are instead combined with polymer-based nanofibers to form the periodic polymer/CENFs host [132], the improvement in the Li wettability and the construction of a lithophilic surface layer by lithophilic nanoparticles or functional groups are always indispensable. 3.3 Separator or interlayer 3.3.1 Separator In LSBs, various complex electrochemical reactions occur between the anode and the cathode. The LiPSs produced by the inevitable shuttling effect react with high-concentration Li+ enriched on the surface of the anode, thereby forming electrolyte-insoluble and non-conductive low-order LiPSs. These low-order LiPSs will be deposited on the surface of the anode, causing deactivation and serious self-discharge. Therefore, a separator is needed between the two half electrodes of LSBs to further inhibit the shuttle effect and suppress the formation of Li dendrites. A separator regulates the movement of Li+ ions, can not only act as a barrier to stabilize the Li+ flux and improve the uneven Li deposition processes on the surface of the anode, but also act as a barrier to LiPSs, and at the same time can protect the cycling stability of the cathodes or anodes in the charging and discharging processes. Electrospun polymer nanofibers possess high SSA, large porosity and excellent advantages in electrolyte uptake and Li+ ions transport. Therefore, they can be used as a flexible and stable separator to suppress the diffusion of LiPSs. Usually, a separator is an electronic insulator, and the electrospun polymer nanofibers can be used as separator without high-temperature carbonization. Compared with commercial PP or PE separators, nonwoven nanofiber film has demonstrated better stability as a separator in the redox environment. Nonwoven nanofiber felts, such as cellulose fibers [133], ceramic fibers [134] and polymer fibers [134], have been widely studied regarding other secondary batteries. Olefin-based polymers (PE or PP) have no specific functional groups, while PAN nanofiber have strong polar cyan groups (C≡N) that can facilitate Li+ ions transferred rate and block the diffusion of LiPSs via the Coulombic interactions. Therefore, pure electrospun PAN fibers can be directly used as a separator [135]. Furthermore, other additives can be added to the PAN electrospinning solution, to make the electrospun separator have Li+ ions permeability and better LiPSs restriction. Zhang et al. [136] added graphene oxide (GO) as an addictive into PAN nanofiber separator, to improve the prepared separator’s electrolyte wettability. Simultaneously, the electrostatic interactions between GO and negatively charged species (Sn 2−) and the high energy binding between CN and LiPSs could both improve the performance for LSBs. Retention loss values as low as 5% can be achieved even after resting for 24 h at a capacity of about 50 mAh g−1. This is not inferior to that of a battery encapsulated with PP or PE separators. A suitable separator in LSBs should act as selective transport channels for Li+ ions, while also severing as a better electrolyte absorber. The polyacrylonitrile-polyether sulfone (PAN/PES)-based electrospun separator [137] has demonstrated better thermal stability (303 °C) and wettability of electrolyte, and has demonstrated better Li+ ions diffusivity and suppression of LiPSs diffusion, compared to a commercial separator. Besides, a flame-retardant polymer can be added to PAN separator to ensure the stability of the battery at high temperatures. As an example, polyacrylonitrile (PAN) and ammonium polyphosphate (APP) were electrospun into a multifunctional separator (PAN@APP) [138]. The abundant amine groups and the phosphate radical in refractory APP were able to suppress the transport of negatively charged LiPSs and free radicals. Thus, the high-temperature performance of LSBs in question was improved. In order to simultaneously solve the problems of the shuttling of LiPSs and Li dendrites growth, modification through chemical grafting of branched polyethyleneimine PEI [139] on PAN separators can provide more polar amino groups, which can regulate the distribution of Li+ ions to keep it uniform and form Li3N-rich SEI layer. This results in dendrite-free Li deposition. Furthermore, amino groups can block the shutting of LiPSs, and can facilitate the capacity retention of the sulfur cathode. Separators fabricated by the electrospinning process and functional group grafting could provide easy and scalable alternatives for solving problems in both the anode and cathode of LSBs. To satisfy with the demand that a separator should adsorb strongly to LiPSs, and be mechanically stable at high temperature (>130 °C), non-flammable nanofiber separators with chemical doping or modified functional group could also be electrospun by other different polymers. For example, a carboxyl functional polyamide acid (PAA) nanofiber separator was prepared via the electrospinning synthesis method [140]. The functional groups of –COOH in PAA separators could promote the transport of Li+ ions, but they may suppress the migration of LiPSs. Further ethanol vapor treatment can also be carried out to increase the porosity and improve the electrolyte wettability of the separator. To further improve the electrolyte affinity and gelation degree, polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF), including F, would be helpful to improve the thermal stability. Recently, a bi-functional double-layer reduced graphene oxide (rGO)-polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF)/PVDF separator was fabricated via a simple electrospinning technique [141]. The porous double-layer membrane separator PVDF provided good thermal stability, and the rGO served as a LiPSs inhibitor and improved the fast transfer of Li+ ions. This separator can significantly enhance the cycling stability and rate capability of LSBs. More recently, many researchers have also chosen poly-m-phenyleneisophthalamide (PMIA) as a separator, due to its excellent thermal stability and outstanding safety. For instance, F-doped tree-like poly-m-phenyleneisophthalamide (PMIA) [142], octa(amino phenyl)silsesquioxane (OAPS) nanoparticles modified PMIA [143], three-flame retardant (di-(2-(5,5-dimethyl-2-sulfide-1,3,2-dioxaphosphinan-2-yl)hydrazineyl)-P-ethylphosphinic) modified PMIA [144], MOFs modified and F co-doped PMIA [145], mangano-manganic oxide (Mn3O4) and F co-doped PMIA [146], multiscale structural poly(vinylidene fluoride hexafluoropropylene) (PVDF-HFP)/poly-m-phenyleneisophthalamide (PMIA) including tetrabutylammonium hexafluorophosphate (TBAHP) [147] have been prepared as separators for LSBs, via electrospinning technology. The electrochemical results of these different separators are listed and compared in Table 4 . The electrospun separators can well effectively prevent huge capacity loss during charging and discharging, even if sulfur and conductive carbon materials are physically mixed directly without heat treatment. This is more prominent when compared with PP or PE separators. These electrospun separators were dependable candidates for the improved electrochemical performance and enhanced safety of LSBs. In a word, most electrospun separators can effectively inhibit the shuttle phenomenon and meet the design requirements for advanced separators. As proposed in a previous review [148], the advanced separators are expected to both trap LiPSs physically and repel LiPSs through chemical interactions. The high porosity, reduced aperture and uniform pore size distribution in the electrospun separators could lead to exceedingly good electrolyte affinity, improved interfacial compatibility and effective suppression for LiPSs, due to physical confinement. However, the impact of physical confinement is too weak, compared with that of chemical confinement. The electrospun separators have surface-rich functional groups. Appropriate element doping, functional groups modifying, polymer grafting and functional layers coating for separators also could facilitate the Li+ ions migration, and could inhibit the diffusion of LiPSs via chemical interactions, thereby effectively blocking the LiPSs. In addition, several polar additives, MOFs, Mn3O4, etc., could give rise to fast redox kinetics, based on the strong catalysis for promoting the oxidation–reduction reaction in the battery. Moreover, the electrospun separators with flame retardant possessed excellent flame retardation, exceptional thermal stability and robust mechanical strength. Simultaneously, the multiscale structure of well-distributed pores also could result in the uniform Li nucleation and the prevention of dendrites growth. Furthermore, adopting double-layer and multilayer designs for separators also could suppress shuttle effect and enhance the catalytic role, resulting in stable long-term cycle performance. The electrospinning method also provides an easy way to fabricates flexible separators with adjustable porosity. The separators, interlayers and electrodes could be directly integrated through an electrospinning process, bringing a chance to investigate the synergistic effect of separators, interlayers and electrodes thus may better solve the shuttle problem. Given the natural advantages of electrospinning in fabricating nanofibers with controllable modification, we believe it could play a great role in the design of functional separators. Moreover, the affinity between electrospun polymer fibers and CENFs for electrodes makes the interface wettability of battery growing appreciable. 3.3.2 Interlayer Apart from as a separator, an interlayer can also exist between the separator and the cathode, which equips the setup with good Li+ ions and electrons conductivity, and excellent electrolyte wettability. Manthiram et al. [149] first proposed that the insertion of a microporous carbon modified membrane as an interlayer (Fig. 11 ) could reduce the internal charge transfer resistance and anchor LiPSs. The functionalization of a microporous carbon membrane between the separator and the cathode can significantly improve the cycle performance of LSBs. The functionalized pores in the interlayer can be used as “LiPSs storage room” to maintain recyclability. First, the diffusion of polysulfide species towards the anode side could be trapped by an interlayer. Second, the conductive and porous carbon-containing interlayers help to reactivate the dead sulfur-containing species and facilitate the complex electrochemical reactions. Comparatively speaking, the function of active sites in host lies in adsorption and catalytic conversion of LiPSs, but an interlayer can better capture LiPSs in electrolyte and promote the conversion of LiPSs to sulfur that adheres to the interlayers, instead of forming dead sulfur in subsequent charging and discharging processes. Therefore, an interlayer acts as a buffer zone for the diffusion and conversion of LiPSs as well as reservoir of electrolyte for ionic transport. In addition, by inserting an interlayer, the formation of sulfur-carbon or sulfur-polymer composite cathodes might be prevented, and the interlayer could indirectly be regarded as a sulfur host. Besides, the interlayer can filter out the freely migrating LiPSs, can observably suppress the severe shuttle effect and can improve the conductivity of the integrated electrode. Therefore, the utilization and functional modification of various types of CENFs, either as an interlayer or in combination with electrospun polymer separators, have been demonstrated to be suitable and advanced components for LSBs. An interlayer adjacent to the sulfur cathode can be coated onto a separator directly. Manthiram et al. [150] proposed this concept, and coated an activated carbon nanofiber (ACNF) onto a polypropylene separator (Fig. 12 ) by means of the electrospinning process. The activated carbon nanofiber (ACNF) possessed a porous architecture with abundant small micropores, and demonstrated high electrical conductivity and effective electrolyte uptake. The interlayer exhibited a significant improvement in the electrochemical utilization and in polysulfide. Therefore, the modification of an interlayer onto a separator as an advanced component in LSBs is a viable approach to designing functional layers with outstanding mechanical strength and flexibility for LSBs. Similarly, directly coating an interlayer composed of PAN and nitrogen-doped carbon black (NC) fibers [151] on pure sulfur cathode (Fig. 13 ) through electrospinning is more conducive to electrolyte permeation for fast Li+ ions diffusion, and provides superior flexibility for adhering onto the cathode. The appropriate flexibility of the fibers is such that it buffers volume expansion, and the additional N-doped porous carbon can provide strong adsorption interaction for LiPSs, and can deliver outstanding conductivity. At the same time, the wetting angle of this modified electrode to the electrolyte is zero degrees, indicating excellent electrolyte wettability. The obtained PAN-NC-coated sulfur cathode (PAN-NC@cathode) has demonstrated stable cycle performance and maintained a reversible capacity of 1030 mAh g−1 with capacity fading of 0.05% per cycle at 200 mA g−1 after 100 cycles. The cathode, interlayer and separator can also be directly integrated through an electrospinning process, which is a breakthrough progress for perfecting an integrated flexible device. In Fig. 14 , sulfur-containing cathode materials and an electrospun PVDF separator were respectively coated on both sides of the carbonized PAN nanofiber felt with MOFs modification [152]. This structure can reduce adverse interface effects, and can improve the synergistic effect of polysulfides confinement, electrons transfer, and Li+ ions diffusion. The soft-pack battery still exhibited stable cycle performance with a high charge/discharge capacity of 716.5/710.6 mAh g−1 at a rate of 0.2 C after 350 cycles in an alternative folded state. This three-in-one membrane demonstrated huge potential in high-energy flexible devices. The functionalized CENFs with good flexibility also can be used as interlayers independently. However, the structural design and porous architecture of CENFs only provide merely palliative solutions but the fundamental problems. The high crystallinity of the graphitic carbon fibers in interlayer [153] could significantly reduce the charge-transfer resistance. Meantime, the elemental doping [154] and modifying functional groups [155] of interlayers can both induce strong adsorption effects and catalytic effects toward LiPSs. This substantially suppresses the shuttle effect, improve the utilization ratio of sulfur, and markedly improve the performance and cycling life of LSBs. Polar components that feature the catalytic conversion effect are becoming increasingly prominent on the cathodes’ side of LSBs, as part of the host. Nevertheless, some polar components are not conducive for electrons transport in the cathode, meaning that LiPSs shuttle effect cannot be inhibited effectively at high rates. These polar components can be loaded onto porous CENFs as an interlayer to realize the rapid conversion of LiPSs and finally generate Li2S/Li2S2. Kang et al. [156] dispersed V2O5 nanoparticles in CENFs (Fig. 15 ) and used the product as an interlayer for LSBs. The V2O5 dispersed on CNFs was able to inhibit the shuttle effect of LiPSs, catalyze redox reaction and work as a high-potential dam to restrain self-discharge. The assembled LSBs demonstrated high capacity and stable cycling lives without obvious capacity fading, indicating that the addition of polar compounds is conducive to further promoting the stable maintenance of capacity. Similarly, some other polar metal compounds with the same ability have also been reported (e.g. TiO2 [157], Ti4O7 [158], CeO2 [159], ZrO2 [160], MnS [161]), all of which can be distributed on/in CENFs in the form of nanoparticles. The electrochemical results of different separators and interlayers are listed in Table 4. Functionalized interlayers play a similar role to functional separators, which mainly contribute to limiting LiPSs. However, reducing the interface resistance between the electrodes and the separators is a unique function for interlayers. Compared with the non-conducting separators, the conductivity of these interlayers provided an additional electrons conduction path [162]. More importantly, after the initial cycles, the redistribution of sulfur from cathodes to interlayers also maintained the capacity of the batteries at a higher level. The reason is that after the first discharge process, some soluble LiPSs’ nucleation starts to react on the interlayer through the electrolyte, thereby increasing the performance of capacity. Compared with the cathodes, the interlayers also have conductive skeleton and catalytic sites, but they play different roles in different regions. The CENFs as sulfur hosts should contain micropores, mesopores and macropores to construct a 3D network structure that ensure the high sulfur content. However, the CENFs as interlayers only require micropores or mesopores to confine the LiPSs physically and provide a capillary force that ensure a stable diffusion of Li+ ions. The macropores and larger pores in interlayers will cause the excessive adsorption of electrolyte and reduce the energy density. Therefore, the addition of interlayers guarantees the stable progress of the electrochemical reaction and is also an effective choice to reduce the proportion of inactive components, while simultaneously improving the utilization of the active components (lithium or sulfur). In addition, the electrospun interlayers can realize the durability service in soft-pack batteries, due to its flexible characteristics. Regarding the current status of the LSBs research field, more and more studies are now focusing on developing high-performance lithium or sulfur hosts, and then on constructing electrocatalytic active sites on separators or interlayers while maintaining high energy density. Fabricating miniaturized and lightweight mobile electronic equipment requires lithium–sulfur energy storage systems with higher energy density. Although electrospun separators or interlayers are excellent for stabilizing charge and discharge, they also indirectly reduce the energy density of the energy storage system by improving the weight of the battery. Therefore, reducing the size and weight of polar nanoparticles while improving their dispersion on/in CENFs to lightening the inactive components of LSBs will become a research hotspot. Currently, few relevant studies have been performed, but those that have are excellent. In addition to enhancing the electrocatalytic effect of interlayers, and regulating LiPSs in the reaction, achieving the stability for the interface between the separator and interlayers/electrodes is also a top priority. 4 Conclusion and prospects Electrospinning is a promising method for developing electrochemical components of LSBs. Here, we have summarized the reasonable and controllable synthesis of different porous CENFs and their applications for LSBs. The porous CENFs can be used on the cathode side as sulfur hosts to suppress shuttling effects, via physical or/and chemical adsorptions. They can also be used on the anode side as lithium hosts to restrain lithium dendrites, by maintaining a uniform lithium nucleation site. Electrospun porous polymer is also a viable alternative to commercial separators and can provide increasing possibilities for separator design. Besides, functional layers can be coated onto both sides of the separator to integrate the components of LSBs, meaning that they can even directly adopt pure sulfur and pure lithium as electrodes. Therefore, the porous CENFs lay a foundation for the commercialization of high-performance LSBs with high sulfur loading and high reversible capacities. Furthermore, the flexibility of CENFs highlights their high potential for high-energy flexible devices that hold great application prospects for wearable and portable electronics. We believe that the porous CENFs will solve the limitations of other materials for LSBs, thus realizing the expectations of high capacity, high rate, rapid charge and discharge, long cycle life, etc. Porous CNFs with different structures prepared by electrospinning technique have better electrochemical characteristics for LSBs. However, they are expected to be further developed in the following aspects, before commercial application: (1) Novel technology and electrospun devices should be developed to efficiently prepare porous CENFs with 3D hierarchical macro/meso/microporous structures, while cutting down the cost. Optimizing the experimental process or simplifying the experimental equipment used CENFs more commercially viable for the large-scale preparation of various components of LSBs. (2) Electrochemical performance is significantly affected by the diameter of nanofibers, pore size/distributions, doped particles and their distributions. Thus, the composition and special structures of the CENFs should be further optimised by selecting suitable and matchable raw materials, and by optimising the process parameters. (3) As known, the element doping, functional groups modification and polar/lithophilic nanoparticles for porous CENFs can efficiently anchor the dissolved LiPSs, suppress Li dendrites and catalytically convert LiPSs/Li2S during cycling. This will significantly improve sulfur utilization, rate capability and cycling life. However, researchers should consider reducing the size of nanoparticles, or decreasing their contents, via the uniform dispersion for lightweight and high gravimetric energy density. Therefore, in the future we will be able to make full use of the advantages of electrospinning technology to uniformly disperse diverse polar nanoparticles, nano-crystals or quantum dots on/in the CENFs. While the physical and chemical stabilities of these nanoparticles, nano-crystals or quantum dots at high temperature are difficult to be guaranteed [163], they might be used coincidentally in separators or interlayers that do not require high temperature treatment. It will also be a promising idea to implement, and is consistent with the hope that the research focus will shift towards separators or interlayers, instead of cathodes or anodes. (4) Due to the high exposure of micro-nano structures under high SSA, significant progress has recently been made in single atomic catalysis (SACs) [164] regarding accelerating LiPSs’ conversion. Some metal SACs on graphene [165,166] or g-C3N4 [167] surfaces have played a significant role in triggering the adsorption and reaction of LiPSs. Single metal atoms can effectively trap dissolved LiPSs and catalyze LiPSs/Li2S conversion (both forward and reverse reactions), thus significantly improving sulfur utilization, rate capability and cycling life of the LSBs. It was predicted that the preparation and dispersion of SACs in CNFs by electrospinning polymers would be a feasible method. However, relatively stable Fe3C [168] and other nanoparticles are often formed in the CENFs, and the current process still needs to be improved. (5) The mechanism analysis of electrochemically active sites in the CENFs for improving the performance of LSBs, including the plating/stripping process of Li nucleation sites, the criteria of LiPSs confinement and the catalytic conversion principle of charge–discharge intermediates, etc., should be further studied using the latest experimental and theoretical tools. (6) The flexibility of CENFs makes them perfect candidates to prepare freestanding, self-supporting, flexible and multiscale components for LSBs that are applied to wearable and portable electronic devices. The integration of components for LSBs through multi-step controllable electrospinning would increase the energy density while maintaining the lightweight nature of the component. However, increasing the pore structures while maintaining the flexibility of CENFs remains challenging. Introducing precursors of active substances into the electrospinning solution, while maintaining the flexibility and cycling stability of the devices, is also a problem that is worth discussing. Although challenges still exist regarding the preparation and application of CENFs for LSBs, porous CENFs with superior porous architectures, high specific surface areas, excellent structural designability, abundant active sites, flexibility and low cost could undoubtedly play a role in commercial LSBs. Electrospinning technology is becoming an important jigsaw to solving the fatal LiPSs shuttling or sluggish sulfur redox. Here, we have discussed the reasonable design and controllable modification for electrospun nanofiber nanostructures, as well as various ways to improve the comprehensive performance of LSBs. It is believed that with combined efforts in electrospinning and electrochemistry, growing strategies will be achieved in constructing high-energy-density and reliable flexible LSBs. These insightful ideas raised during the exploration will eventually become important prospects to realizing the commercialization of LSBs in the future. Bai, Nanoscale 5 (2013) 4902–9, https://doi.org/10.1039/c3nr33927k. Zhaoming Tong received his bachelor's degree in material at the Wuhan University of Science and Technology in 2018. He is currently pursuing his master’s degree at the Wuhan University of Science and Technology. His research interests focus on the design of electrospun nanofiber-based new energy materials for Li–S batteries. Liang Huang received his B.S. degree in 2010 and Ph.D. degree in 2015 from China University of Geosciences (Wuhan). He joined in Singapore National University as a research assistant in 2014 and undertook a Visiting Scholar and Postdoctoral Associate in University of Wyoming from 2014 to 2016. Currently, he is an Associate Professor at The State Key Laboratory of Refractories and Metallurgy, Wuhan University of Science and Technology. His current research focuses on design of novel materials for catalysis, semiconductor and energy applications via DFT calculations. Wen Lei is an Associate Professor of Materials Science and Engineering at The State Key Laboratory of Refractories and Metallurgy, Wuhan University of Science and Technology. He received his Ph.D. degree from Huazhong University of Science and Technology in 2018. Currently, his research interests are energy and storage materials and devices. Haijun Zhang received his PhD Degree in University of Science and Technology Beijing in 1999. After two year working as a postdoctoral fellow at Functional Material Research Laboratory of Tongji University, he joined High Temperature Ceramics Institute, Zhengzhou University in 2001, and promoted to Associate Professor and then full Professor there. In 2007, He joined Prof. Toshima’s group at Tokyo University of Science Yamaguchi as a full-time researcher scientist. Currently, he is a full Professor at The State Key Laboratory of Refractories and Metallurgy, Wuhan University of Science and Technology. His research interests include refractories, high-temperature ceramics and nanostructured materials as well as their promising applications. Shaowei Zhang is currently Professor and Royal Society Industry Fellow in the College of Engineering, Mathematics and Physical Sciences at University of Exeter, UK. Before moving to Exeter, he had worked for about 14 years in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering at University of Sheffield, as Postdoctoral Research Associate, EPSRC Advanced Fellow, Lecturer and Reader. His main research interests are in the processing, microstructures and properties of structural and functional materials, and current research topics include: low temperature fabrication of nanomaterials, novel synthesis of 2-D quantum dots, exploration of 2-D nanocatalysts, and preparation of porous ceramics and ceramic matrix composites. Other work includes formation of functional coatings, and development of novel armour materials and ultrahigh-temperature ceramics.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium–sulfur batteries (LSBs) have become promising next-generation energy storage technologies for electric vehicles and portable electronics, due to its excellent theoretical specific energy. However, the low conductivity of sulfur species, notorious lithium dendrites, the severe “shuttle effect” of polysulfides (LiPSs) and the inferior kinetic reaction for LiPSs/Li2S conversion during discharge–charge have seriously hindered their practical application, and also pose potential safety hazards. Owing to their superior porous architectures, high specific surface areas, excellent structural designability, functional modifiability, abundant active sites and flexibility of carbon-containing electrospun nanofibers (CENFs), they exhibited the superior characteristics that can simultaneously solve the above issues. In this review, we summarize the recent progress and application of CENFs in LSBs. First, we provide a brief introduction to the structure and composition controlled of carbon nanofibers by electrospinning. We then review progress in recent developments of CENFs for LSBs including cathodes, anodes, separators, and interlayers. We focus on how to solve practical issues that arise when the CENFs are applied to various parts of LSBs, and the relevant working mechanisms are described, from high sulfur loading and Li dendrites suppression to LiPSs’ confinement and conversion. Finally, we summarize and propose the existing challenges and future prospects of CENFs, for the design and architecture of electrochemical components in Li–S energy storage systems.
